dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: This Transportation Librarians Roundtable presents an outline of various working styles and the categories for each that are part of the Michigan Model of Leadership developed at the University of Michigan. The four categories of work styles are Red (building strategic structures), Blue (driving robust results), Yellow (fostering a collaborative community), and Green (enabling creative change). Twenty-two respondents participated in a self-assessment prior to the presentation. Bob Cullen shares the results of the self-assessment and opened the topic of work styles among librarians for discussion.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: Wyoming Department of Transportation Research Manager Enid White’s presentation covers copyright issues related to artificial intelligence (AI). There are differing perspectives as well as many lawsuits underway in this area of copyright law. Generative AI companies and Large Language Models mine data from the internet to train AI. Authors, researchers, and other creators want credit and compensation for their original works when used to train AI. While some AI companies obtain consent when they use data scraping tools, others do not, claiming that the use of AI does not trigger the rights protected by the Copyright Act and if it did it would fall under the Doctrine of Fair Use. White provides an overview of Fair Use, Copyright, text and data mining, and responses from the U.S. Government and AI companies pertaining to intellectual property.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: Eric Schwarz describes a digitization project at the New Jersey Department of Transportation Research Library. The project, supported by the Transportation Research and Connectivity Pooled Fund, contains materials about significant eras or events in New Jersey's transportation history. Among the collections are photos, videos, departmental reports, and employee newsletters produced between 1921 and 2023. Schwarz discusses best practices for digitization projects including selecting materials, cataloging, and promoting the collection. The collection is available on the Internet Archive at https://bit.ly/njdot-ia

mods.abstract: With the post-pandemic transition to remote and hybrid work, employees at the Michigan Department of Transportation adopted varying schedules. Jennifer Herron leveraged technology to provide library services in changing times and boost remote engagement. Tools discussed include online meetings, managing notification settings, increasing digital support, virtual office hours, request forms, and use of an appointment system. Herron provides demonstrations of Microsoft Power Apps, Microsoft Forms, SharePoint, Viva Engage, Trello, Zotero, and OneNote.

mods.abstract: Gabrielle Hysong discusses changes at the Rolls-Royce Library during the COVID-19 pandemic. Prior to the pandemic, the Rolls-Royce Library was a social hub and collaborative space. Hysong developed strategies for providing library services in remote and hybrid work environments. Post-Covid, the library moved to a new, downsized location that offered the opportunity to transform the collection. Outreach efforts to employee resource groups, new employees, presentations to global teams, and attending departmental meetings are strategies used to promote library services.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: Michael Molina and Christine Kline talk about the 2020 pooled fund study for the transportation librarians community. Objectives were to identify the current transportation information infrastructure, survey the needs of state departments of transportation, develop a cooperative digitization project, update a toolkit for non-librarians, and enhance communication among group members. The study produced a synthesis report on current practices and future directions of transportation librarians.

mods.abstract: Librarians from the U.S. Government Publishing Office (GPO) present an overview of the GPO’s library services. Jessica Fomalont gives a brief history of the agency and talks about major programs including the Federal Depository Library Program that provides free, ready, and permanent public access to Federal Government information. Fomalont also discusses the Cataloging & Indexing Program and Adelaide Hasse, who developed the SuDoc classification system that catalogs documents by agency. Jessica Tieman discusses the GovInfo Repository, which is a fully ISO:16363 certified Trustworthy Digital Repository. GPO is also an Affiliate Archive of the National Archives and Records Administration. GovInfo ingests an average of 4,000 submission information packages per week. Oksana Osborne shares how the GPO collaborates with the cataloging community. GPO has begun experimenting with Linked Data by adding URIs to bibliographic records linking them to name or subject authority records. GPO also contributes to the Library of Congress Subject Headings controlled vocabulary, partnered with the Library of Congress on a BIBFRAME project, and participated in testing of the Official RDA Toolkit.

mods.abstract: Speakers Timothy Creagan, Senior Accessibility Specialist from the U.S. Access Board and Kelsey Flynn, Technical Information Specialist with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, provide training on Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act and methods for libraries to make information accessible. Section 508 requires Federal agencies to procure, develop, maintain, and use information and communication technology that is accessible to people with disabilities. Creagan and Flynn discuss the importance of accessible information and standards for meeting accessibility requirements. The presentation covers technology, content examples, creating accessible documents, screen readers, disability sensitivity, website design, accessibility aids, and training. This Transportation Librarians Roundtable was part of a multi-month series focusing on Inclusion, Diversity, Equity, and Access (IDEA), and the practical and professional applications of those values in our libraries and on behalf of those who we serve.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: Kenn Bicknell, Manager of Policy, Research, and Library Services for the Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority Research Library & Archive, discusses how the library works to be “future-ready”. The agency has expanded the mobility agenda while reducing resources for a library that serves a big community. With limited staff and budget, and an increase in data and knowledge, the Metro Library set priorities to maximize its resources. Bicknell describes how implementing strategic directions with core services supports sustainability in libraries. Transformative initiatives such as collecting, curating, and disseminating news related to L.A. transportation have resulted in collaborations with other libraries. Digitization of the collection and then promoting historical assets helped built a sense of community across many disciplines.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: In this Transportation Librarians Roundtable, Enid White provides tips on how to manage 508 compliance within programs and libraries. Section 508 applies to the development, procedure, maintenance, and use of documents and programs. It’s set up to assist those without vision, with limited vision, without perception of color, tunnel vision, cataracts, dyslexia, with limited language, cognitive, and learning disabilities. Programs cannot ask to be exempt from 508 compliance because you can’t ask stakeholders to waive their rights to having a 508 compliant document or shift the burden to stakeholders. White describes steps to manage 508 compliance, create accessibility statements, provide funding to ensure compliance, and types of documents which should be 508 compliant.

mods.abstract: The 2021 edition of the Transportation Librarians Roundtable Annual Open Forum Community Discussion was moderated by Bob Cullen and Samantha Strain. Participants discussed the Transportation Research Board’s annual meeting, held virtually for the first time in 2021 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This session also covered how work/life balance has been impacted as more people worked from home during the pandemic and different organizations’ plans for returning to in-person work. The conversation included perspectives on digital versus physical collections and turning the pandemic into an opportunity to increase digitization of library materials.

This session also covered how work/life balance has been impacted as more people worked from home during the pandemic and different organizations’ plans for returning to in-person work. The conversation included perspectives on digital versus physical collections and turning the pandemic into an opportunity to increase digitization of library materials.

mods.abstract: A.J. Million, Research Investigator at the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR) at the University of Michigan, presents research on change management for librarians. New government administrations can bring periods of turbulence, including restructuring libraries. After the new Secretary of State in Missouri restructured the Missouri State Library, Million conducted interviews with people involved and submitted FOIA requests for emails. Million found that five themes emerged and that there’s tension in top-down, mandated changes. The presentation encourages library organizations to participate in lobbying and advocacy at the state and local level.

mods.abstract: Equity Data Science Fellows at the U.S. Department of Transportation Cyrus Chimento and Alex Curtis share their work in transportation equity. Chimento discusses active transportation, and the goal of collaborating to develop national geospatial data products for bicycling and walking networks and ADA facilities for the National Transportation Atlas Database (NTAD). Active transportation sits at the convergence of equity, environment, health, and economic concerns in transportation. National authoritative datasets allow for tracking progress, inform policy, and systems-level analysis. Curtis discusses the digitization of PR-511s, which are records of the U.S. Interstate system. These records track each state’s progress in building proposed and funded Interstates. The goal of digitizing PR-511s is to provide a canonical copy of these data for preservation of critical historical transportation information. Interstates built near neighborhoods created noise pollution and vehicle emissions, negatively impacting quality of life for historically marginalized communities. Using funds from the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, the PR-511 data can help repair damage caused by transportation development and work towards racial equity. This Transportation Librarians Roundtable was part of a multi-month series focusing on Inclusion, Diversity, Equity, and Access (IDEA), and the practical and professional applications of those values in our libraries and on behalf of those who we serve.

mods.abstract: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) plays an important role in the standards community. Kathryn Miller, Publishing Services Librarian at the NIST Research Library and Museum, shares how NIST responded to the problem of exclusionary, biased, and harmful language in standards and standards-related research. The Library collaborated with the Standards Inclusivity Effort to update the NIST Technical Series Publications author instructions with new sections on inclusive language. They also created inclusive language guidance for NIST staff who participate in standards development activities. This Transportation Librarians Roundtable was part of a multi-month series focusing on Inclusion, Diversity, Equity, and Access (IDEA), and the practical and professional applications of those values in our libraries and on behalf of those who we serve.

mods.abstract: Senior Librarian Kendra Stoll shares historical preservation efforts at the Caltrans Transportation Library. Historic preservation began with C.R. “Bob” Krieger, who collected over 30 years of maps, photographs, inactive reports and records, personal recollections, and objects related to the California Department of Transportation’s history. Milestones for the library include collecting the Highway Recollections Oral Histories (1977-1999), the formation of the Caltrans History Preservation Committee (1984-2018), collecting the Loma Prieta Earthquake Oral Histories (1989), digitization of California Highways and Public Works (2019), and digitization of early Biannual and Annual Reports dating from 1895. Collections are available from the Caltrans Transportation Library website at https://dot.ca.gov/programs/transportation-library/library-collection

mods.abstract: Michael Molina presents three case studies from the Oklahoma Transportation Library designed to forge networks and connections within agencies. The three case studies – Knowledge Management, the Pooled Fund Study, and Workforce Development – demonstrate effective methods for connecting the library with the agency it serves. Molina addresses funding, time management, and ways to overcome obstacles. Building networks helps raise awareness for your library, demonstrates the value of your library, creates library champions, and increases capabilities to address agency problems.

mods.abstract: Speakers Leni Oman, Andy Everett, Kathy Szolomayer, and Christy Granquist identified challenges in using data and information. As members of the Washington State Department of Transportation (WSDOT) Vocabulary Team, a Subcommittee of the WSDOT Data Governance Council, the group found that employees spend between 15% and 50% of their time looking for the data and information they need. Funded by a FHWA grant, the group sought to improve findability of information through application of metadata guided by the F.A.I.R. Principles. Recommendations included creating an enterprise glossary that defines key terms used at WSDOT, creating taxonomies using information standards, and developing an enterprise thesaurus.

mods.abstract: Cara Marcus, Resource Center Manager for the National Rural Transit Assistance Program (National RTAP), discusses the evolution of three websites. The National RTAP Resource Library website was migrated to a new platform with streamlined navigation, greater interactivity, and a modern design. The new site features an online library mega menu with information and library resources. The second site that Marcus demonstrates is Resource Share. Resource Share is a library of rural transit resources developed by National RTAP that’s continually being updated. For the third website, Marcus shares the browsing and searching functionality of the Transportation Technical Assistance Coordination Library (TACL) online catalog.

mods.abstract: Curators Megan MacCall and Laura Stroffolino from the Free Library of Philadelphia discuss the development of transportation in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. They showed some highlights from “Philadelphia: The Changing City”, an in-person exhibition that they co-curated. They also give some highlights of the 1876 U.S. Centennial Exhibition held in Philadelphia. Digitized collections include 19th and 20th century photos and maps of transportation in Philadelphia. If an item was digitized, the caption on the slide includes the Item ID number and you’ll be able to search by that number when visiting the digital collections page at www.freelibrary.org/digital.

mods.abstract: The topic for this Transportation Librarians Roundtable is succession planning. Presenters Cara Marcus and Bob Cullen offer insights on how succession planning is a crucial element in an organization’s strategic planning. Succession planning helps prepare for a smooth transition from outgoing to incoming employees. Marcus describes four steps in succession planning: preparation, skills, training, and creating the plan. Marcus also shares succession planning templates developed for the National RTAP Transit Manager’s Toolkit. Cullen provides a definition of knowledge management as it relates to succession planning, defining the major types of knowledge as explicit knowledge, tacit knowledge, and cultural knowledge. Librarians are important to succession planning because of their organizational connectivity skills. Maintaining continuity while also minimizing disruptions is an outcome of succession planning.

mods.abstract: Librarians from the National Transportation Library (NTL) share updates about their projects and accomplishments during the year. Mary Moulton provides details about new collections in ROSA P, digitization projects, and the use of LibApps tools to organize information. Jesse Long and Leighton Christiansen discuss the Omnibus Survey Program, the Vehicle Inventory & Use Survey (VIUS), and working with legacy data. Xin Wang and Vinod Koduri give an overview of NTL’s system infrastructure and improvements. Lisa Curtain presents projects completed during a summer STIPDG internship.

mods.abstract: With traditional vehicles, safety consisted of crashworthiness and electrical/mechanical reliability. Emerging, disruptive technologies such as driver-vehicle interface, driving automation systems, intelligent transportation systems, and advanced driver-assistance systems (ADAS), safety moves from the human to the cyber-physical system. Presenters from SAE International and the University of California, Berkeley discuss the challenge of safety assurance and the process of developing technology standards.

Presenters from SAE International and the University of California, Berkeley discuss the challenge of safety assurance and the process of developing technology standards.

mods.abstract: With the rapid transition to remote work during the COVID-19 pandemic, this TLR was an opportunity for transportation librarians to discuss their experiences and observations. Hosts Bob Cullen and Sam Strain posed topics including: How has your organization responded to the COVID-19 crisis? How have your responsibilities, information requests, or delivery of services shifted as a result of the crisis? What have been your biggest lessons learned while working either from home or at your organization throughout this difficult time? Participants shared professional and personal experiences during this challenging time.

mods.abstract: Librarian Jennifer Herron with the Michigan DOT Library presents an overview of predatory publishers. Herron’s interest began with looking at predatory mobile phone applications that pretended to be medical devices and evolved into learning about predatory publishers. There are three main types of predatory publishers: oblivious offender, phisher, and hijacker. Some predatory journals are new publications with good intentions that don’t understand the importance of peer-review and other elements that go into making a good research journal. This TLR includes examples of how to identify a hijacked journal. Herron also shares tips for authors to avoid falling for predatory publishing practices.

mods.abstract: Jennifer Klang, Head of Reference Services at the Department of the Interior Library, presents this edition of the Transportation Librarians Roundtable. Visible web content includes web pages that search engines can crawl and index. Invisible web content includes databases, password-protected websites, public records on government sites, intranets, message boards, website archives, forums, and online library catalogs. Klang shares search strategies and resources for uncovering invisible web content that doesn’t get indexed or queried by search engines.

mods.abstract: Karen Neinstadt, Reference and Outreach Librarian at the Minnesota Department of Transportation (MnDOT) Library, presents an overview of who uses data at MnDOT, types of data used, and how the data is used. Neinstadt discusses communication plans and the need for MnDOT employees to know the ethnic populations in the community when preparing information sessions about a transportation project. Data provided by the MnDOT Library is important for ensuring proper cultural relevance, translating materials, observing various information-seeking behaviors, and marketing products appropriately to the communities they serve. This Transportation Librarians Roundtable also covers how the MnDOT Library gathers and analyzes the data.

mods.abstract: Jason J. Bittner highlights key intellectual property (IP) management and copyright issues relevant to running a transportation research enterprise. Bittner’s perspective is that there are three main areas of copyright pertaining to the transportation community: works for hire, public domain, and fair use. Bittner covers the principles of copyright best practices for each of these areas. Emerging issues related to copyright permissions in journals include self-plagiarism, take down notices, co-authors and copyright ownership, and licensing agreements.

mods.abstract: Amanda J. Wilson, Chief of the Office of Engagement and Training at the National Library of Medicine, presents this edition of the Transportation Librarians Roundtable. Wilson was the Director of the National Transportation Library from 2006-2017. This talk includes a history of the Network of the National Library of Medicine (NNLM), case examples of networks within the NNLM, and comparisons of the NNLM and the National Transportation Knowledge Network (NTKN). During this webinar, Wilson also reflects on how the transportation and medicine sectors overlap.
Introduction by Bob Sweet.

mods.abstract: As an embedded and solo librarian for MED-EL, Weinberger shares background information about corporate libraries in D-A-CH (Germany, Austria, Switzerland) countries. Weinberger describes embedded librarianship as taking a step outside the context of traditional library settings and traditional library services. Embedded librarians can be service providers and also form partnerships with their clients. Weinberger recommends being realistic about the needs of your clients and where the information professional fits into the organization.

mods.abstract: This Transportation Librarians Roundtable features a funded project from the Transportation Library Connectivity and Development Pooled Fund Study. Maggie Sacco, Lawrence E. Decina, and Tia Mastromatto describe how the goals of the project were to improve the process of filling out Form 1700.7. TransAnalytics, LLC won the bid on the project and conducted a survey of state department of transportation libraries and research centers. Objectives included documenting the current state of practice in the use of Form DOT F 1700.7 and identifying methods that will encourage more effective use of the form. Improving the process of filling out the form could improve compliance and increase access to transportation information by researchers and practitioners.

mods.abstract: Joseph A. Busch, Founder and Principal Consultant at Taxonomy Strategies, covers two main topics in this Transportation Librarians Roundtable. The first is metadata and interoperability – why metadata is important and how you talk to managers about it. The second is data management challenges – how we bring together structured and less structured information. Busch also explains metadata schemes like Dublin Core and metadata vocabularies like the Transportation Research Thesaurus. Metadata is designed to create enough information for any user, tool, or program to find and use any piece of content.

mods.abstract: The internet is the preferred source of information for most people. A.J. Million’s dissertation work on the technical infrastructure underpinning state department of transportation websites is the focus of this Transportation Librarians Roundtable. Million discusses how the design of this back-end infrastructure – servers, programs, networks, and software – impacts how people can do their jobs. The organization of how technical infrastructure services are provided influences the quality of those services and sometimes presents barriers.

mods.abstract: Leighton Christiansen, Librarian at the Iowa Department of Transportation, leads a conversation about the pressures of transportation libraries. Transportation libraries are being asked to provide instant electronic access and increase services while budgets and staffing are shrinking. Christiansen encourages transportation libraries to be agile – like a modern academic research library – to provide instant access where they can. Topics covered include building core transportation collections, downsizing physical library environments, and ways transportation libraries can emulate research libraries.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: Transportation Governance and Finance: A 50-State Review of State Legislatures and Departments of Transportation was released in November 2016, and is intended to serve as a comprehensive, up-to-date reference tool for state governments, as well as for other interested stakeholders, about how all 50 states and the District of Columbia govern and pay for their transportation systems. Jennifer Brickett and Jaime Rall discuss the creation of the report, describe the types of information found in the report, and look in-depth at one state’s profile. After the session, librarians, information professionals, and readers of the report will be able to more quickly locate the information from the report they are seeking.

mods.abstract: Information and Metadata Architect Andy Everett with the Washington State Department of Transportation (WSDOT) presents this webinar. Everett describes how WSDOT developed an information strategy, goals for data management, and the metadata repository. The process of creating WSDOT’s metadata repository involved developing a core metadata schema and extending it by developing a reference and open data schema. WSDOT developed taxonomies and controlled vocabularies to support this initiative. The goal is to manage WSDOT language to help people predictably find trusted information, in support of business decision making and, through connectedness, foster collaboration and common understanding.

mods.abstract: The Digital Public Library of America (DPLA) is a free, national digital library that provides access to materials from libraries, archives, and museums across the United States. Samantha Gibson, Engagement and Use Coordinator, talks about what the DPLA is and what they’re working on. The collection consists of cultural heritage materials – primarily representing U.S. history and culture – including art, books, maps, photographs, paintings, physical objects, moving images, audio recordings, oral histories, manuscripts, and archival documents. The DPLA is a network of partners, a portal, a platform, and a public option.

The DPLA is a network of partners, a portal, a platform, and a public option.

mods.abstract: The Transportation Research Board (TRB) initiated a new project to ensure that they sent the right publications to the right people at the right time. Central to this project is making sure that state departments of transportation receive the right quantities of publications in the right format. They focused on electronic access first; a physical copy at the state DOT library second; and individual hard copies as needed. Michael LaPlante, Director of Finance with the TRB, speaks about beta testing the project and invites two state librarians who participated in the beta test to share their experiences and challenges.

mods.abstract: Speakers Roberto A. Sarmiento and Jennifer Boteler collaborated on a project to develop a template for collection development policies. Their goal was to develop a flexible and scalable collection development policy template that could become a first step towards the development of a much-needed national cooperative collection development policy. This Transportation Librarians Roundtable covers an overview of the project, the methodology for developing the template, a brief look at the template, and testimonials from volunteers who used the template.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: The Swedish National Road and Transport Research Institute (VTI) hosts the Swedish National Library for the transportation research sector. Speaker Birgitta Sandstedt provides an overview of the transport research portal and its sub-portals. For example, the Library won a contract with the Swedish Energy Agency based on a proposal for a subject portal. The proposal aimed to collect, structure, and disseminate research and development covering the program’s output. Sandstedt demonstrates several of the Library’s sub-portals and how they connect with larger databases such as the Library’s catalog. The Library actively seeks new business opportunities, new ways of getting funding from contracts with external customers, and ways to maximize impact and usefulness of their knowledge and experience.

mods.abstract: Highway construction sites are one of the most dangerous jobs in the world. Research Librarian Hong Yu with the Texas A&M Transportation Institute shares the mission of the National Work Zone Safety Information Clearinghouse: “To provide the transportation construction industry and the general public with comprehensive information to improve motorist, worker, and pedestrian safety in roadway work zones.” Yu provides an overview of the Clearinghouse’s history and funding; how the Clearinghouse website evolved; usage worldwide and customer feedback; and resources available in the Clearinghouse.

mods.abstract: The District Department of Transportation Library was founded in 2011 after going through various incarnations over the years. mods.abstract: Steve Hanson blended librarianship with skills as a certified project management professional to become a Project Librarian. Hanson shares project management best practices, lessons learned, and skills developed during various projects. This Transportation Librarians Roundtable also covers information architecture, process maps, creating timelines, and recommended tools to support project management.
In addition to the webinar, host Bob Cullen and Roberto Sarmiento give a tribute to former Northwestern Transportation Librarian Mary K. “Kay” Geary who passed away on March 1, 2016.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: University of California, Riverside Archivist Bergis Jules presents an overview of the “Document the Now” project. Funded in December 2015 by the Mellon Foundation, this project was started because Michael Brown was killed in Ferguson, Missouri. Watching the events unfold on social media presented an opportunity to think about archiving in that space. The project aims to address ethics, rights, and privacy issues around collection, preservation, and access to social media data. Jules also discusses developing a community around social media archiving.

mods.abstract: The NTKN Digitization Working Group (DWG) is a subgroup of the National Transportation Knowledge Network (NTKN) that is focused on digitization efforts to improve access to transportation information. The group, formed in June 2009, has a broad charge to develop a digitization agenda for transportation information collections. Amanda Wilson and John Cherney share an overview of the DWG, the results of an environmental scan on digitization within the transportation community, and a look at next steps the group envisions from their results.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: This session of the Transportation Librarians Roundtable marks a return to the group updates format. Michael Molina discusses the origins of the Pooled Fund Study, current work as it gets ready to wind down in 2025, and outcomes from the project. With 18 members from states across the U.S., the study resulted in digitization of thousands of materials, creation of a transportation librarian’s toolkit, and development of LibGuides on transportation research topics. Enid White shared news from AASHTO’s summer Research Advisory Committee (RAC) meeting held at the end of July. There were good discussions regarding artificial intelligence in the transportation world. White provided an overview of a panel of 4 individuals who talked about different areas of AI. Cara Marcus talked about the Special Libraries Association (SLA) Transportation Community. This year’s SLA Annual Meeting was held at the University of Rhode Island and was the first in-person business meeting since before the pandemic. There was a social meeting of the transportation and engineering librarian communities, informal meetings, posters, and educational events.

mods.abstract: Before 2020, the Minnesota Department of Transportation (MnDOT) Library’s born-digital publications were stored in many places. Along with an increased need for digital delivery, the library needed a place to store all MnDOT-produced publications and make them available. Speakers Marilee Tuite, Library and Information Services Manager for the Center for Transportation Studies at the University of Minnesota, and Maddie Kuncio, Digitization and Reference Librarian at the MnDOT Library, share their experience in building a digital library. Tuite discusses the need for a digital library dedicated to MnDOT publications and the process of working with a state vendor to develop the repository platform. Kuncio provides a live demo of the MnDOT Digital Library’s public interface and the Drupal-based back end.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: Are you responsible for creating electronic documents that are shared with the public or even internally with coworkers? Do you post PDFs, images, or other documents to your website, intranet, or on social media? To be more inclusive--and to meet legal requirements--you need know how to make your documents accessible. Rather than remediating them after the fact, learn how to create your documents with accessibility in mind from the start. Though not an intensive, in-depth training, this presentation will guide you through features in MS Word and MS PowerPoint that will help make a good faith effort. This presentation is intended to help you take steps to be more inclusive to patrons and coworkers of all abilities and to become an accessibility liaison at your organization, encouraging others to learn these necessary skills.

Speaker Bio: Ms. Kevyn Barnes is the Manager of Library Services at the TxDOT Research Library (operated at the Center for Transportation Research-UT Austin) and has served as its webmaster since 2010. Her focus is on the capture of knowledge, cataloging, and dissemination of transportation research materials and information, particularly via web services. She actively works with the TxDOT’s Research & Technology Implementation Division to develop and improve library web resources and oversees the library’s social media and other methods of outreach. In 2014, the University of Texas at Austin mandated that all websites on its domain meet minimum accessibility scores of 90% compliance with WCAG 2.0 Level AA, per statutory requirements in Texas Administrative Code 206.70 Accessibility Standards (TAC 206.70). Because the library’s catalog made up almost half of the Center’s web pages, she was responsible for bringing the Center’s score up from 24% compliance to over 90% in just a few months. Now that the website has achieved a stable score of 99% conformance, she has turned her focus to the electronic documents that the library hosts for free online access. Although not an expert in the field of accessibility, she will relay what she has learned and provide information about tools that she uses to create accessible documents.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: This Transportation Librarians Roundtable (TLR) focuses on issues of copyright that impact librarians' work on a regular basis, using a "Copyright Triage” approach. Part 1 discusses the basics of copyright use, centered on the ways in which copyright is indeed all around us (bringing into play everything from how one becomes a copyright owner to the length of time for a copyright) and also how contracts affect all aspects of copyright. The featured speaker is Nancy Sims, the Copyright Program Librarian at the University of Minnesota. Aside from being a librarian and copyright specialist, Nancy is also a lawyer. This combination of library and legal experience has given her a broad and unique perspective on the prevalence of copyright concerns in our everyday lives.

mods.abstract: This Transportation Librarians Roundtable (TLR) gives an overview of the services offered by AASHTO resource and focus on various types of information (their newsletter, other documents, data) that are available for librarians and others via their recently revamped website. This is a non-technical presentation on technical sources intended to be helpful for members of the transportation librarian community and those whom they serve. Kim Swanson is the featured speaker for this TLR. She is the communications manager for the AASHTO resource program (previously known as AMRL), which is based in Frederick, Maryland. AASHTO resource is a part of AASHTO's Engineering and Technical Services division. The program provides assessments and other types of information for construction materials testing laboratories.

mods.abstract: Dale Thompson and Gene McHale provide an overview of the US DOT’s new data capture program. The vision of the Data Capture and Management Program (DCM) is active acquisition and systematic provision of integrated, multi-source data to enhance current operational practices and transform future surface transportation systems management. Their work focuses on a connected vehicle program where vehicles collect and exchange data with other vehicles. As that data is being shared, there’s an opportunity for safety applications and improved transit coordination.

mods.abstract: Iowa DOT Librarian Leighton Christiansen presents this Transportation Librarians Roundtable on web-scale discovery. Current library catalog technology has challenges with discovery: collection size, format variety, electronic access, remotely hosted content, interface diversity, user search preferences, and full text delivery. If something is not discovered, it cannot be used. Web-scale discovery provides a single search across a library’s full range of collections for quick searches of librarian-curated content.

mods.abstract: Knowing more about generations in the workplace is a valuable tool. For the first time in history, we have four generations in the workplace and the fifth is just entering the workforce. With that many different generations in the workplace, we’re seeing some conflicts and some opportunities that we haven’t seen in the past. Amanda Holland with the Alaska Department of Transportation and Public Facilities shares information about how understanding generational differences can help decrease conflict, improve morale, and is a survival tool for managers.

mods.abstract: Paul Burley, Technical Services Librarian at the Northwestern University Transportation Library, covers two topics in this Transportation Librarians Roundtable. The first topic was creating authority records in RDA, and the second was creating a new books list in WorldCat. Authority records are important for maintaining the consistency of entities in our records in a standardized form and to establish relationships between other entities. RDA replaced AACR2 and has some different elements for authority records. The books list feature on WorldCat lets anyone create an account and use it to build lists of new books available at the library.

mods.abstract: The invisible web includes content that doesn’t get indexed or queried by current generation search engines, content that isn’t retrievable for one reason or another, and content that resides in searchable databases that produce dynamic results. This presentation by Jennifer Klang, Head of Reference Services at the U.S. Department of Interior Library, shares lessons in how to search the internet more effectively with a research-oriented approach.

mods.abstract: George Franchois, Director of the United States Department of the Interior Library, talks about initiatives to improve library services and resources for American Indian Libraries. The Department of the Interior Library conducted a survey of Tribal College and University Libraries to ask about their needs. Based on the survey results, a new American Indian Libraries Initiative working group was formed through FEDLINK. One accomplishment was getting FEDLINK membership for Tribal College and University Libraries that will enable them to obtain discounted, federal government pricing. Goals of the group include building an information culture; creating a clearinghouse of resources among participants; identifying federal efforts to support American Indian Libraries in their preservation, digitization, cataloging, and reference services efforts; and integrating event and training opportunities.

mods.abstract: Emiko Atherton, Director of the National Complete Streets Coalition, and Jana Lynott, Senior Strategic Policy Advisor with AARP, present this month’s Transportation Librarians Roundtable. Atherton represents a coalition that’s focused on creating and building safe streets for people of all abilities and for all users. This approach to transportation planning considers multiple modes of transportation and changing design to change behavior. Lynott manages AARP’s transportation research agenda and shares data points and resources that AARP offers. Lynott emphasizes the importance of having a safe travel environment in helping people stay engaged in their community.

mods.abstract: This Transportation Librarians Roundtable (TLR) is the second installment of a two-part presentation series entitled "Copyright Triage." Part 2 discusses how copyright ownership does not mean absolute control, and includes key copyright concepts for librarians. The featured speaker is Nancy Sims, the Copyright Program Librarian at the University of Minnesota. Aside from being a librarian and copyright specialist, Nancy is also a lawyer. This combination of library and legal experience has given her a broad and unique perspective on the prevalence of copyright concerns in our everyday lives.

mods.abstract: This Transportation Librarians Roundtable (TLR)addresses how transportation librarians -- particularly when it comes to compliance with the standards and requirements of Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 -- can help facilitate web accessibility. The discussion covers assistive technologies, Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, and best practices for creating and evaluating accessible websites. The featured speaker is Jared Smith, of WebAIM (Web Accessibility in Mind), a non-profit organization that focuses on lowering various information technology barriers for individuals with disabilities.

mods.abstract: The European-based “HERMES” project aims to enhance collaboration between researchers in transportation around the world. Dr. George Kotsikos with the School of Mechanical and Systems Engineering at Newcastle University provides an overview of the HERMES project. The project was created in response to the European Commission’s call for providing international cooperative transportation research and encouraging sharing of research results. Core activities for the HERMES project are development of the Transport Research Portal and engaging researchers by creating conditions for closer international collaboration.

mods.abstract: The FIA Foundation is an international philanthropy focused on safe and sustainable transportation. Along with the World Health Organization, the FIA Foundation launched the United Nations Decade of Action for Road Safety for 2011 to 2020. Dr. Bella Dinh-Zarr, Road Safety Director with the FIA Foundation, presents an overview of the Make Roads Safe campaign. The Make Roads Safe campaign was initiated to raise public and political awareness about highway safety. Specifically, organizers are working to raise traffic safety as an issue on the UN agenda so that traffic-related deaths and injuries will be recognized and addressed as an international health, transportation, and development priority.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: Librarians from the National Transportation Library (NTL) present the 2023 Annual Report. Mary Moulton discusses new and forthcoming collections at the NTL, navigation improvements for ROSA P, web archiving content from the Bureau of Transportation Statistics, and the Science.gov refresh. Xin Wang talks about the NTL repository upgrade project Workroom 3.1. This project will improve the back end of the repository used for cataloging individual records and batch processing. Jesse Long shares news that the NTL joined the Federal ORCID Consortium and is updating the US DOT Public Access Plan. The Data Services Team also completed two major projects: implementing the CURATED Workflow to improve data curation strategies and a data rescue project of the TIUS/VIUS reports using ABBYY FineReader. Archivist/Historian Eden Orelove describes efforts on developing the US DOT Special Collections, the process of acquiring and sorting historic DOT materials, and the creation of a secure room for archives at DOT headquarters. Rosalyn Alleman shares updates about NTL Reference services, including an increase in inter-library loan fulfillment, performing in-depth literature reviews, and responding to questions from DOT staff. Alleman also coordinates the National Transportation Knowledge Network and provides outreach about NTL services.

mods.abstract: During this last meeting of 2022, librarians from the National Transportation Library (NTL) present the 2022 annual report. Mary Moulton shares information about new collections in ROSA P, collection development and digitization projects, and collaboration with federal agencies. Moulton also provides an update about changes coming to the DOT Public Access plan. Reference Librarian Rosalyn Alleman shares updates about new outreach and programming initiatives. Highlights from the Reference Team include responding to research requests for Secretary Buttigieg’s office and other DOT staff, providing database training to DOT staff, and updating FAQs. Peyton Tvrdy, graduate student at the University of Illinois, discusses her practicum experience at the NTL. Tvrdy shares the process of learning to catalog and working on a legacy data rescue project.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: NTL interns Naomi Coleman, Jacob Ham, and Maria Lee describe a reparative cataloging project focused on the FTA 50th Anniversary collection in ROSA P. This collection is important is because of renewed interest from the public and policymakers in mass transportation and the historical preservation of an important time period for transportation research. The project involved identifying appropriate metadata fields for bulk updates, prioritizing 508 compliance remediation, enhancing metadata, applying uncontrolled keywords for Inclusion, Diversity, Equity, and Access (IDEA), and deduplicating records. This presentation covered some limitations of the Transportation Research Thesaurus: how it lacks sufficient terms to index transportation research that relates to people; index terms that are not descriptive enough or are outdated; the need to reevaluate and update older terms; and the emerging practice in the field of using communities’ preferred terminology. Coleman, Ham, and Lee also discuss limitations of the NTL’s Workroom system that does not provide multiple controlled vocabularies and how this project was a proof-of-concept for subject term research. This Transportation Librarians Roundtable was part of a multi-month series focusing on Inclusion, Diversity, Equity, and Access (IDEA), and the practical and professional applications of those values in our libraries and on behalf of those who we serve.

Lee, Maria
dc.description.abstract: NTL interns Naomi Coleman, Jacob Ham, and Maria Lee describe a reparative cataloging project focused on the FTA 50th Anniversary collection in ROSA P. This collection is important is because of renewed interest from the public and policymakers in mass transportation and the historical preservation of an important time period for transportation research. The project involved identifying appropriate metadata fields for bulk updates, prioritizing 508 compliance remediation, enhancing metadata, applying uncontrolled keywords for Inclusion, Diversity, Equity, and Access (IDEA), and deduplicating records. This presentation covered some limitations of the Transportation Research Thesaurus: how it lacks sufficient terms to index transportation research that relates to people; index terms that are not descriptive enough or are outdated; the need to reevaluate and update older terms; and the emerging practice in the field of using communities’ preferred terminology. Coleman, Ham, and Lee also discuss limitations of the NTL’s Workroom system that does not provide multiple controlled vocabularies and how this project was a proof-of-concept for subject term research. This Transportation Librarians Roundtable was part of a multi-month series focusing on Inclusion, Diversity, Equity, and Access (IDEA), and the practical and professional applications of those values in our libraries and on behalf of those who we serve.

mods.abstract: David Gansz, Director of the National Transportation Library, discusses how information has come to be treated as a commodity, which has had a profound impact on libraries and librarians. Gansz proposes an alternative to measuring the value of libraries via quantifiable transactions like gate counts, checkouts, clicks, and downloads. Libraries can demonstrate value through storytelling. Collecting and collating success stories transcends traditional assessment practices and provides librarians an effective method of communicating impact.

mods.abstract: At the final Transportation Librarians Roundtable (TLR) for 2024, librarians from the National Transportation Library (NTL) shared annual updates. Rosalyn Alleman provided an overview of Reference Team accomplishments, knowledge management, TLR activities, and social media and outreach efforts. Beth Burnett described ROSA P metrics, initiatives including a new technical services ticketing system and new metadata policy, and completing the project cataloging the TLR backlog. Jesse Long discussed NTL’s Core Trust Seal application, new guidance for SMART Grants data management plans, updated policies, and new tools developed to increase efficiency for data services. Eden Orelove gave an overview of archives projects including outreach activities, new acquisitions, creating a new website and collections catalog, and processing special collections.

Leighton Christiansen presents information about data management and the new Public Access Data Management Plans collection at the NTL.

mods.abstract: Summer Transportation Internship Program for Diverse Groups (STIPDG) intern Madeleine Poche spent ten weeks interning at the National Transportation Library’s Archives under the mentorship of Archivist/Historian Eden Orelove. In this TLR, Poche presents the four projects that comprised the internship: assisting in processing the Secretary of Transportation Speeches collection; creating social media content for NTL’s X account; assisting with Archives-hosted events; and writing web content for the NTL Archives future web pages. Poche reflects on the highlights of working with U.S. Department of Transportation archival materials and the variety of experiences during the internship.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: The National Transportation Library (NTL) undertook a major initiative in 2014 focusing on upgrading, stabilizing, and enhancing NTL’s digital repository platform. Requirements of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy’s Public Access Plan Memo, NTL’s expanded legislative mandate under MAP-21, and developments in the repository field have all come together to create momentum around considering upgrading our repository platform. A critically important component to a sustainable archive dedicated to long-term preservation is demonstration of trustworthiness. Mary Moulton, Digital Librarian with the NTL, discusses work in researching and gathering information in trustworthy repository certification.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: To help commemorate the 10th anniversary of the debut of the Transportation Librarians Roundtable (TLR), Amanda Wilson serves as this TLR's speaker. Amanda Wilson played a vital role in planning and launching the TLR in 2007, and, for most of the past decade, served as its guiding light. The presentation discusses how the TLR came into existence and how it evolved over the years, and also reflects on various changes that have become an integral part of our professional and personal lives since 2007, and how these changes (the ever-growing applications of social media as a key example) have ultimately influenced the content and character of the TLR presentations.

mods.abstract: This Transportation Librarians Roundtable (TLR) introduces the National Transportation Library's new digital repository, the Repository and Open Science Access Portal (ROSA P). National Transportation Library (NTL) staff introduce ROSA P, and invite users to participate in testing the new software during a soft launch phase.

dc.publisher: United States. Department of Transportation. National Transportation Library
mods.abstract: This Transportation Librarians Roundtable (TLR) focuses on the USDOT Public Access Plan and its implications for transportation librarians. The speakers include Amanda Wilson, National Transportation Library (NTL) Director; Charles Ducker, Senior Departmental IP Counsel; Tim Klein, Acting Director, Technology and Policy Outreach, Office of the Assistant Secretary for Research and Technology; Dan Morgan, Chief Data Officer; Alasdair Cain, Director, Research Coordination, Office of the Assistant Secretary for Research and Technology; Mary Moulton, NTL Digital Librarian; and Beyan Johnson, IT Specialist for Research Coordination, Office of the Assistant Secretary for Research and Technology.

mods.abstract: This webinar reviews various aspects of the U.S. DOT Public Access Plan, including: Opening U.S. Government-Funded Research Data; U.S. DOT Public Access Review; Submitting Final Reports and Final Datasets; Benefits of Data Management; Writing Data Management Plans; and, Implementing Data Management Plans. [Recording length: 52 minutes]
